body_html:
this is because MaxPool's downsampling is ambiguous in input shape (several input shapes can be mapped to the same output shape).

That's why, we provide: output_size as the third optional argument to the call operator: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/nn/modules/pooling.py#L243
(i should document this).

You can do:

import torch
from torch import nn
from torch.autograd import Variable

data = Variable(torch.rand(1, 3, 540, 960))

pool = nn.MaxPool2d(2, 2, return_indices=True)
unpool = nn.MaxUnpool2d(2, 2)

out, indices1 = pool(data)
size1 = out.size()
out, indices2 = pool(out)
size2 = out.size()
out, indices3 = pool(out)
size3 = out.size()

out = unpool(out, indices3, output_size=size2)
out = unpool(out, indices2, output_size=size1)
out = unpool(out, indices1)

That's why, we provide: output_size as the third optional argument to the call operator: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/nn/modules/pooling.py#L243

size3 = out.size()

out = unpool(out, indices3, output_size=size2)
out = unpool(out, indices2, output_size=size1)
out = unpool(out, indices1)
body:
this is because MaxPool's downsampling is ambiguous in input shape (several input shapes can be mapped to the same output shape). 

That's why, we provide: `output_size` as the third optional argument to the call operator: https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/nn/modules/pooling.py#L243
(i should document this).

You can do:

```
import torch
from torch import nn
from torch.autograd import Variable

data = Variable(torch.rand(1, 3, 540, 960))

pool = nn.MaxPool2d(2, 2, return_indices=True)
unpool = nn.MaxUnpool2d(2, 2)

out, indices1 = pool(data)
size1 = out.size()
out, indices2 = pool(out)
size2 = out.size()
out, indices3 = pool(out)
size3 = out.size()

out = unpool(out, indices3, output_size=size2)
out = unpool(out, indices2, output_size=size1)
out = unpool(out, indices1)
```
